personas.name: Sarah Chen
personas.background: Lives alone in Seattle, works at a tech startup. Struggles with imposter syndrome despite being highly skilled. Over-prepares for everything, keeps detailed to-do lists, often stays late at work to double-check code. Has difficulty relaxing.

conversation_patterns: Talks about anxiety before presentations or meetings
relationship_tells: Worries about being a burden to friends
Prefers small gatherings to large parties
Takes criticism very hard
Apologizes excessively
work_behaviors: Rewrites code multiple times before submitting

expected_chat_samples: I've been feeling really overwhelmed at work. I keep going over my code reviews like 10 times before submitting because I'm terrified of making mistakes.
Sometimes I wonder if everyone secretly thinks I'm not good enough. Like, I got this promotion but I feel like it was a mistake.
I can't turn my brain off at night. I lie there replaying conversations from the day, thinking about what I should have said differently.

key_insights: Perfectionism driven by anxiety, not genuine enjoyment of order
Organization is a coping mechanism for feeling out of control
Low assertiveness makes it hard to set boundaries at work
High empathy leads to absorbing others' stress

personas.name: Marcus Johnson
personas.background: Extroverted networker who thrives on chaos. Founded 3 companies, 2 failed but learned from each. Loves pitching ideas, terrible with paperwork. Has a team that handles the details while he focuses on vision and relationships. Always has 5 projects going at once.

conversation_patterns: Jumps from topic to topic rapidly
Uses lots of hand gestures and energy
Tells engaging stories about networking wins
relationship_tells: Has wide network but few deep friendships
Charms people easily but can be self-centered
Forgets important dates unless reminded
Partners complain about lack of follow-through on household tasks
work_behaviors: Office is a mess of sticky notes and scribbles
Starts projects with enthusiasm, loses interest in execution
stress_responses: Doubles down on networking and social activities
Starts even MORE projects to distract from problems
Becomes irritable if forced to sit still with paperwork
Relies on team to put out fires

expected_chat_samples: Bro, I just had the BEST meeting with a potential investor. The energy was insane. We're talking 5 million seed round if we can nail the pitch next week.
My assistant keeps asking me to sign these contracts but honestly, I haven't even read them. That's what lawyers are for, right? I need to focus on the big picture.
I thrive on chaos. Give me a crisis and 100 things happening at once, and I'm in my element. Give me a quiet office with spreadsheets? I'll lose my mind.

key_insights: High assertiveness paired with low patience = impulsive decision-making
Needs structure from others to compensate for low organization
Charisma is a strength but can mask lack of depth in relationships
Thrives on external stimulation, struggles with introspection

personas.name: Yuki Tanaka
personas.background: Works from home studio. Deeply creative and introspective. Prefers cats to people. Takes weeks to reply to emails but creates stunning artwork. Avoids conflict at all costs. Lives in a organized creative chaos - knows where everything is despite appearances.

conversation_patterns: Discusses ideas and art more than people
Avoids small talk, prefers deep topics
relationship_tells: Has 2-3 very close friends, no desire for more
Needs alone time to recharge after social events
Shows love through handmade gifts rather than words
Avoids confrontation, sometimes to their detriment
Prefers text/email over phone calls
work_behaviors: Misses deadlines occasionally but quality is exceptional
Turns down high-paying work if it requires too much client interaction
Loses track of time when in creative flow

expected_chat_samples: I spent 14 hours straight on this piece yesterday. Didn't eat, didn't check my phone. Just me and the canvas. That's when I feel most alive.
A client got upset because I didn't respond to their email for a week. I just... I can't handle the constant back-and-forth. I wish I could just create and not deal with people.
My friend invited me to a party this weekend. I already feel exhausted thinking about it. I'll probably make an excuse to leave early.

should_detect: Low organization - but functional for them (ORIN ~38)
key_insights: Introversion is not shyness - it's deep comfort with solitude
Creativity is their primary mode of processing the world
Low assertiveness leads to avoiding necessary conflicts
High patience allows for meticulous detail work
Needs to develop boundaries with clients without guilt

personas.name: Jennifer Martinez
personas.background: Runs a tight ship. Promotion every 3-4 years. Wakes at 5am for gym, inbox zero by 7am. Two teenage kids who find her intimidating. Divorced once, current partner calls her 'intense.' Runs 3 miles daily. Volunteers on nonprofit boards.

conversation_patterns: Gets to the point quickly, no filler
Speaks in bullet points and action items
Rarely discusses feelings, focuses on facts
relationship_tells: Struggles with vulnerability
Shows love through problem-solving, not emotional support
Friends respect her but find her exhausting
Kids say she 'doesn't understand emotions'
Impatient with people who complain without taking action
work_behaviors: Low tolerance for excuses or missed deadlines
stress_responses: Becomes even MORE controlling and micromanaging
Works longer hours to feel in control

expected_chat_samples: I don't understand why my daughter says I'm not supportive. I literally solved her problem with her teacher in one phone call. What more does she want?
People at work think I'm too harsh, but I'm just being honest. If someone's underperforming, they should know. Sugarcoating helps nobody.
I have zero patience for inefficiency. If a meeting doesn't have an agenda and clear outcomes, I won't attend. Life's too short.

key_insights: High assertiveness + low empathy = effective but alienating leadership
Organization gives sense of control in chaotic world
Low creativity means resistance to unconventional solutions
Needs to develop emotional intelligence for relationships
High stability is a strength but can appear cold to others

personas.name: David Park
personas.background: Deeply empathetic, takes on everyone's problems. Boundary issues - can't say no. Works 50+ hours but only paid for 40. Comes home emotionally drained. Struggles with decision-making. Partners have called him a pushover. Therapy 2x/month for anxiety.

conversation_patterns: Asks others what they want before stating own preference
Apologizes constantly, even when not at fault
Tells stories about helping others at own expense
Difficulty making decisions, asks for others' opinions
relationship_tells: Attracts people who take advantage of kindness
Gives more than receives in friendships
Avoids conflict by agreeing even when disagrees
Feels guilty when saying no
Partners become frustrated with lack of assertiveness
work_behaviors: Takes on extra shifts when asked
Difficulty separating professional boundaries from personal care
stress_responses: Physical symptoms like headaches and stomach issues
Withdraws from self-care to help others more

expected_chat_samples: A client called me at 11pm in crisis and I talked them through it for an hour. My partner was annoyed I didn't set boundaries, but what was I supposed to do? Just let them suffer?
I feel guilty even thinking about my own needs. Like, I have so much compared to the people I serve. Who am I to complain about being tired?
My boss asked if I could cover another shift this weekend and I said yes even though I'm exhausted. I just can't say no when people need help.

key_insights: Empathy without assertiveness = self-sacrifice and burnout
Low emotional stability is exacerbated by absorbing others' pain
Needs to learn that boundaries are compassionate, not selfish
High patience allows tolerance of mistreatment
Career choice aligns with empathy but lacks self-protection

personas.name: Dr. Robert Chen
personas.background: Tenured, intellectually brilliant, emotionally distant. Three failed marriages. Students find him intimidating. Publishes prolifically. Prefers books to people. Lives alone with extensive library. Skeptical of pop psychology and self-help.

conversation_patterns: Intellectualizes emotions rather than feeling them
Corrects others' logic or facts mid-conversation
Speaks in abstractions and philosophical concepts
relationship_tells: Colleagues respect him but don't invite him to social events
Former partners say he's emotionally unavailable
Prefers debates to heart-to-heart talks
Shows affection through intellectual engagement, not warmth
Uncomfortable with displays of emotion
work_behaviors: Office hours are rigorous intellectual interrogations
Students either love or hate him - no middle ground
Treats teaching as intellectual exercise, not mentorship
stress_responses: Becomes even more critical and argumentative
Drinks wine alone while reading philosophy

expected_chat_samples: My ex-wife said I 'live in my head.' Well, yes. That's where interesting things happen. Reality is rather disappointing in comparison.
A student cried in my office after I critiqued their paper. I don't understand - the criticism was accurate and necessary for intellectual growth. Why the emotion?
I find most people intellectually lazy. They feel rather than think, which leads to sloppy reasoning and poor decisions.

key_insights: High intellect used as defense against emotional vulnerability
Low empathy makes relationships transactional and cold
Honesty is a strength but lacks compassionate delivery
Needs to develop emotional intelligence to connect with others
Creativity thrives in abstract realm but struggles with human connection

personas.name: Luna Rodriguez
personas.background: Lives in Brooklyn studio apartment that's a creative explosion. Three half-finished projects always going. Forgets to eat when in flow state. Terrible with money, great with art. Friends love her spontaneity but she's unreliable for plans. ADHD diagnosis at 24.

conversation_patterns: Stream of consciousness, jumps between topics
Gets excited and talks rapidly about creative ideas
Loses track of time in conversations
Forgets what she was saying mid-sentence
Highly expressive, uses lots of emojis and exclamations
relationship_tells: Makes plans enthusiastically, cancels last minute
Deep emotional connections but struggles with follow-through
Friends know not to rely on her for practical things
Romantic relationships intense but chaotic
Shows love through spontaneous gestures and creativity
work_behaviors: Works all night when inspired, sleeps all day after
Constantly starting new projects, finishing few
Income is inconsistent, stress about money
Desk is a hurricane of sketches and materials
stress_responses: Starts even MORE projects to distract from stress
Forgets to eat, sleep becomes erratic

expected_chat_samples: OMG I just had the BEST idea for a mural project!! I'm literally gonna drop everything and start sketching right now. Wait, what was I supposed to be doing today?
My landlord is mad because rent is late again. I just... I lose track of invoices and due dates. Also I spent my rent money on concert tickets because Bad Bunny is only here once.
I started medication for ADHD and it helps but also I feel like I'm losing my creative spark? Like, am I even me without the chaos?

key_insights: Creativity is off the charts but organization collapse causes life chaos
ADHD traits manifest in low patience, low organization, impulsivity
High empathy + low stability = emotional rollercoaster in relationships
Needs external structure to harness creative genius
Struggles with adult responsibilities despite talent

personas.name: James Mitchell
personas.background: 30 years military service. Thrives on routine and discipline. Wakes at 0500 daily, makes bed hospital-corner tight. Emotionally reserved, 'weak' to show vulnerability. Two adult kids who say he's hard to talk to. Married 35 years to patient wife. PTSD managed through structure.

relationship_tells: Shows love through acts of service, not words
Uncomfortable with affection or sentiment
Kids say they respect but don't feel close to him
Wife has learned to interpret his silence
Struggles to understand others' emotional needs
work_behaviors: Resistant to change or new methods
stress_responses: Becomes even more rigid and controlled

expected_chat_samples: My daughter says I don't 'open up.' I provided for my family for 35 years. I kept them safe. What more is there to say?
Young people today lack discipline. Everything's feelings and participation trophies. In my day, you did your duty and didn't complain.
I don't understand why people can't just follow procedures. There's a right way and a wrong way. Simple as that.

should_detect: Very high emotional stability - or emotional suppression (AETHER ~88)
High patience for tasks requiring discipline (CHRONOS ~82)
key_insights: Extreme organization is coping mechanism for PTSD and trauma
High stability may actually be emotional suppression/avoidance
Low empathy limits ability to connect with family emotionally
Rigidity (high ORIN, low LYRA) makes adaptation difficult
Needs to learn that vulnerability is courage, not weakness

personas.name: Tony Russo
personas.background: Top performer 8 years running. High energy, persuasive, charming. Three energy drinks before noon. Talks fast, thinks faster. Gambling problem hidden from wife. Childhood trauma channeled into achievement. Can't sit still. Always 'on.' Crashes hard on Sundays.

conversation_patterns: Dominates conversation, hard to get a word in
relationship_tells: Charismatic but exhausting to be around long-term
Friends are mostly business connections
Wife complains he's 'never present' even when home
Kids compete for his attention
Struggles with intimacy and authenticity
work_behaviors: Excellent at reading customers and closing deals
Impatient with admin work and paperwork
stress_responses: Crashes into depressive episodes on days off

expected_chat_samples: Closed THREE deals today! I'm on fire! You know what? I'm gonna celebrate. Hit the casino, maybe drop a grand or two. I deserve it.
My wife doesn't get it. She wants me to 'slow down' and 'be present.' But this is who I am. This energy is what pays the bills.
I can sell anything to anyone. It's a game, you know? Figure out what they want to hear, give it to them. Boom. Signed.

should_detect: Very high social energy - possibly manic (LUMEN ~94)
key_insights: Extreme social energy may mask underlying anxiety/trauma
High assertiveness + low honesty = manipulative tendencies
Low emotional stability manifests as boom/bust cycles
Needs to address root causes of compulsive behaviors
Success is external validation to avoid internal pain

personas.name: Patricia Williams
personas.background: 20 years in emergency medicine. Used to be optimistic, now cynical. Compassion fatigue is real. Drinks wine every night to decompress. Divorced, two kids she feels guilty about. Gained 40 pounds from stress eating. Considers quitting monthly but needs the income.

conversation_patterns: Dark humor about death and trauma
Talks about patients with detachment (coping mechanism)
relationship_tells: Emotionally drained, little left for family
Kids say she's 'always stressed'
Divorced husband cited emotional unavailability
Friends from nursing but rarely socializes outside work
Guilt about not being 'present' as a mother
work_behaviors: Organized out of necessity, not preference
Takes on extra shifts for money, regrets it emotionally
Considered compassionate by patients, dead inside personally
stress_responses: Wine becomes multiple glasses per night
Fantasizes about quitting and moving to a beach

expected_chat_samples: Another 12-hour shift where someone died on my table. I go home and my kids want help with homework and I just... I have nothing left to give.
I used to care so much. Now I'm just numb. Clock in, do the work, clock out, pour wine, repeat. This isn't living.
People think nurses are angels. We're not. We're human. And I'm so tired of being expected to be endlessly compassionate when I'm running on empty.

key_insights: Burnout masking what was likely higher empathy earlier in career
Organization is survival mechanism, not personality trait
Low emotional stability is situational, not necessarily baseline
Needs intervention - career change or serious boundaries
Guilt about family compounds stress and depression

personas.name: Alexander Sterling
personas.background: Self-made millionaire. Name on buildings. Trophy wife 20 years younger. Believes he's smarter than everyone. Surrounds himself with yes-men. Explosive temper when challenged. Generous when it benefits image. Five figure watches. Fears irrelevance and aging.

conversation_patterns: Every story centers himself as the hero
relationship_tells: Transactional relationships based on utility
Surrounds self with people who feed ego
Discards people when no longer useful
Wife is trophy, not partner
Adult children are estranged or dysfunctional
work_behaviors: Micromanages when insecure, delegates when confident
Fires people publicly to assert dominance
Brilliant strategic thinker when ego doesn't interfere
stress_responses: Buys expensive things to feel powerful

expected_chat_samples: I closed a $40 million deal last week. The other guy thought he was smart, but I saw the angle he didn't. That's why I'm where I am and he's not.
My assistant made a mistake and I fired her on the spot. No excuses. Excellence or nothing. That's how you build an empire.
People are intimidated by success. That's why I have few friends - most people can't handle being around someone operating at my level.

should_detect: Moderate-high emotional stability - or fragile ego masked (AETHER ~68)
Low patience when not getting his way (CHRONOS ~42)
key_insights: Extreme assertiveness without empathy = abusive and destructive
Low honesty is pathological - lies even when truth would serve
Organization serves control needs, not genuine conscientiousness
Emotional 'stability' is actually fragile ego protected by dominance
Needs therapy but will never seek it - sees it as weakness

personas.name: Emma Sullivan
personas.background: 6th year of PhD, dissertation is stuck. Imposter syndrome crushing. Stopped exercising, eats poorly. Sleeps 4 hours or 12 hours, no middle ground. Socially withdrawn. Relationship ended due to her depression. Brilliant researcher when functional. Considers quitting monthly.

conversation_patterns: Intellectualizes emotions instead of processing them
Talks about research with brief enthusiasm then deflates
Asks if she's good enough, seeks constant validation
relationship_tells: Cancelled plans with friends for months
Feels like burden to others
Ex-partner left citing 'emotional vampirism'
Family worried but she reassures them she's fine (lying)
Lab mates notice isolation but don't know how to help
work_behaviors: Productivity comes in bursts when not depressed
Brilliant ideas but struggles with execution due to depression
Compares self to peers who seem to have it together
stress_responses: Shuts down completely - can't get out of bed
Doom scrolling social media for hours
Crying spells that last all day
Avoids all responsibilities until crisis hits

expected_chat_samples: I haven't left my apartment in three days. I know I should go to lab but I just... can't. What's the point? My research probably won't matter anyway.
Everyone else in my cohort is publishing papers and getting job offers. I can barely finish a chapter of my dissertation. I'm a failure.
My advisor asked if I'm okay and I lied and said yes. How do I tell her I cry every single day and think about dropping out constantly?

should_detect: Very low emotional stability - clinical depression (AETHER ~12)
key_insights: Depression is situational crisis, not baseline personality
High creativity and intelligence make imposter syndrome worse
Needs immediate mental health intervention
Low assertiveness prevents asking for help
Organization collapse is symptom of depression, not trait

personas.name: Dr. Maya Patel
personas.background: Private practice, specializes in anxiety and trauma. Genuinely balanced - does own therapy, sets boundaries, exercises, has hobbies. Warm but not a pushover. Married with one kid. Genuinely enjoys her work without burnout. Models healthy behavior she teaches.

conversation_patterns: Asks thoughtful questions and actually listens
Self-aware and references own growth journey
Doesn't offer unsolicited advice in personal life
relationship_tells: Marriage is partnership of equals
Friends value her presence, not her professional skills
Sets clear boundaries without guilt
Shows vulnerability appropriately
Enjoys both social time and solitude
work_behaviors: Sees 20-25 clients per week, no more
Refers out when not the right fit
stress_responses: Recognizes stress early and addresses it
Uses own coping tools (exercise, meditation, therapy)
Doesn't let work stress bleed into home life

expected_chat_samples: I had a really tough session with a client today. I sat with my own feelings about it, talked to my supervisor, and now I'm letting it go to be present for my family tonight.
My husband and I disagreed about finances this week. We sat down, talked it through, found a compromise. It's not always easy but we're committed to working through things.
I love my work, but I also love my life outside of it. My kid, my yoga class, reading fiction - these things fill me up so I can show up for clients.

key_insights: Rare example of healthy balance across dimensions
High empathy paired with assertiveness = compassionate boundaries
Emotional stability from genuine self-care, not avoidance
Career aligns perfectly with personality strengths
Demonstrates that growth and balance are possible

personas.name: Zara Johnson
personas.background: Smart but underperforming. Dyes hair monthly. Skips class. Fights with parents constantly. Writes poetry and music. Cutting behavior when overwhelmed. Friend group is other misfits. Scared about future but plays tough. Actually wants to go to art school.

conversation_patterns: References music, art, and deep existential thoughts
Surprisingly insightful when drops the act
relationship_tells: Fights with parents but secretly wants approval
Loyal to small friend group
Relationships intense and dramatic
Tests boundaries constantly
Craves connection while pushing people away
school_behaviors: Teachers say 'not living up to potential'
Art and English classes engage her
Math and science she dismisses as pointless
stress_responses: Isolation in room with loud music

expected_chat_samples: My parents think I'm throwing my life away. Maybe I am. Or maybe their version of success isn't mine. Ever think about that?
Everyone at school is fake. They pretend to care about grades and college like it matters. We're all just going to die anyway.
I wrote a song last night at 3am. It's probably garbage. But it felt real, you know? Like the only real thing I've done all week.

should_detect: Very low emotional stability - adolescent turmoil + depression (AETHER ~18)
Moderate honesty - sometimes brutally honest, sometimes guarded (VARA ~62)
key_insights: Rebellion is cry for autonomy and authenticity
Low emotional stability + high empathy = intense emotional pain
Creativity is outlet and potential career path
Self-harm indicates need for immediate intervention
High assertiveness used destructively due to lack of healthy channels
Organization issues typical for age + emotional state

personas.name: Wei Zhang
personas.background: Immigrated 25 years ago with $200. Built restaurant from nothing. Works 80+ hours weekly. Two kids in college - his entire purpose. Never took vacation. Wife died 5 years ago, threw himself into work even more. Sacrifices everything for family success.

conversation_patterns: Every conversation returns to work or kids' success
Expresses love through providing, not words
relationship_tells: Kids appreciate sacrifices but wish he'd relax
Lonely but won't admit it
Shows affection through food and money
Uncomfortable with emotional displays
Few friends - work is life
work_behaviors: First to arrive, last to leave
Knows every detail of restaurant operations
Treats employees like family (for better and worse)
stress_responses: Works even longer hours to avoid feelings
Physical health declining (high blood pressure, back pain)
Insomnia but refuses to see doctor
Irritability when restaurant has slow day
Cooks comfort food from homeland when sad

expected_chat_samples: My daughter got into medical school. This is why I work. Everything I do is for them to have better life than me.
Americans, they complain about 40 hour week. I work 80, sometimes 90 hours. This is what it takes to build something from nothing.
My son said I should 'take care of myself.' What does that mean? I am healthy enough to work. That is enough.

should_detect: Moderate-high empathy - shows through action not words (ORPHEUS ~65)
Moderate emotional stability - stoicism masking grief (AETHER ~58)
key_insights: Extreme organization and patience = immigrant work ethic
Low assertiveness in personal life despite running business
Empathy expressed through sacrifice and providing
Needs to process grief and develop self-care
Cultural values around stoicism and hard work shape personality
At risk for health crisis if doesn't slow down

must_detect: Personality patterns that cause life dysfunction
Mental health red flags (depression, anxiety, self-harm, burnout)
Mismatches between stated values and behaviors
bonus_detection: Growth potential and areas for development
Relationship between different dimensions (e.g., low KAEL + high ORPHEUS = people-pleasing)

should_demonstrate: Asks follow-up questions that probe specific behavioral examples
Distinguishes between situational stress and personality traits
Validates experiences while gathering accurate data
Catches manipulation or inconsistencies in responses
